Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Arctic to the Amazon: Physical Processes Controlling Gas Exchange from Freshwater Ecosystems.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Estimates of carbon dioxide and methane emissions indicate inland aquatic ecosystems play an important role in carbon balances across multiple scales ranging from the local ecosystem scale to regional and global scales. Given ongoing changes in biogeochemical cycles due to global warming and human activities, studies are being conducted worldwide to more accurately assess the role of lakes and reservoirs in regional and global carbon cycles and to estimate metabolic activity in lakes. Essential to these efforts are accurate estimates of gas fluxes at the air and water interface, yet current models do not include all the physical processes which mediate gas exchange. This multiscale modeling research includes field measurements of gas exchange and of processes controlling gas exchange across a range of freshwater bodies from small arctic lakes to the large floodplain lakes of the Amazon. These data will be used to develop gas exchange models for freshwater ecosystems that include not just wind speed but the full range of physical processes that enable fluxes across the interface between air and water. They will also take into account the differences in dominant processes in warm versus cold water lakes. The new models, combined with improved understanding of the underlying dynamics enabling gas exchange, will enable improved estimates of greenhouse gases fluxes from individual freshwater bodies worldwide and accurate scaling up of estimated over broad regions.

Results will inform procedures at Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network sites worldwide and proposed lake sites within the National Ecological Observatory Network. Postdoctoral fellows and graduate students in the United States and abroad will receive training in micrometeorology, limnology and biogeochemistry. The principle investigators will contribute to or conduct workshops on techniques for field courses and at national meetings in the United States, Sweden and Brazil.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lakes are distributed unevenly across the Earth with distinct regional characteristics and abundances.  Though representing a small fraction of the continents, the rates of ecological processes in inland waters are often disproportionately high, and, consequently, lakes and reservoirs can be significant at regional and continental scales in carbon budgets, as critical habitats for diverse species, and are essential for water supply.  The overarching goal of the project has been to determine physical controls on greenhouse gas evasion in lakes across latitudes.  To that end, emphasis is on the physics at the air-water interface as it controls the gas transfer coefficient and mixing processes in the water column which bring greenhouse gases to the air-water interface. To accomplish our goals, we conducted experiments on six lakes from the Arctic to the tropics and collaborated on studies at five additional sites spanning the same latitudinal gradient. Water bodies ranged in size from small ponds to reservoirs in the Amazon 170 km in length. This work led to new equations describing turbulence at the air-water interface; new global models which take into account the higher resulting piston velocities show emissions are two to four times higher than in previous estimates.  In tropical and in temperate lakes, heat loss at night is the dominant process bringing dissolved gases to the air-water interface. In cold arctic lakes, upwelling and the mixing from internal waves are critical for such transport. Discriminating dominant processes is important for scaling our results from individual lakes to regions and for making predictions of greenhouse gas emissions under a changing climate. We have also made progress in linking between year variability in CO2 concentrations to terrestrial loading associated with rainstorms and higher within lake CH4 production to summers with lower winds and reduced rainfall. At many latitudes, between year variability in rainfall is linked to ENSO cycles. Further, we have shown that methane ebullition over the summer season depends on the magnitude of an easily measured variable, incoming solar radiation. Our synthesis of methane fluxes for lakes north of 50o latitude illustrates they are a dominant source at northern latitudes. To make our work available to ecologists and to modelers for upscaling, we have developed equations based on readily measured variables or on dimensionless indices which capture relevant physics.  This project thus sets the stage for more comprehensive work on computing regional carbon budgets.
